DOC.HEAD: Top Aides to Noriega Arrested; Vatican Urges Noriega To Leave
Eds: LEADS with 30 grafs to UPDATE with two more Noriega aides detained, music continues outside Vatican embassy; picks up 28th, `Endara, whose...'
LaserPhoto PAN22
DOC.TEXT: U.S. troops arrested an Israeli intelligence expert and five other close aides to Manuel Antonio Noriega, U.S. sources said. The Vatican today said it was urging Noriega to leave its embassy. The deposed military leader was holed up in the embassy with 17 others. For the first time since the U.S. invasion Dec. 20, U.S. sources said there was no shooting overnight. Newspapers in Panama City today ran advertisements asking people to bring back looted merchandise, offering rewards with no questions asked. In other ads, companies such as Kodak said warranties would not apply to looted items. Army Lt. Col. Jerry Murguia, a U.S. military spokesman, said Noriega's chief economic adviser and his personal physician were detained within the past 24 hours. Angel Mina, Noriega's economic chief, was detained trying to leave the country, Murguia said today. Murguia also said that Dr. Sosa, whose first name was not available, was caught while trying to enter the Cuban Embassy. U.S. troops arrested Michel Harari, a former Israeli intelligence agent and top security adviser to Noriega who was an instructor for Noriega's Panamanian Defense Forces, a U.S. Embassy officical said Thursday on condition of anonymity. Lt. Col. Roberto Cedeno, chief of Noriega's state security intelligence, also was detained. Harari and Cedeno were not previously in the Vatican embassy but it was not known where they were arrested. Two more top aides, Lt. Col. Carlos Velardes and Lt. Col. Arnulfo Castrejon, left the embassy and were taken into custody by U.S. troops, said U.S. Army Lt. Col. Jerry Murguia. Velardes was chaplain of the Defense Forces, and Castrejon was the officer on duty at Noriega's military headquarters on Dec. 16, the day an unarmed U.S. Marine officer was killed nearby. They are among more than 4,000 people being held without charges, U.S. sources have said. The Vatican for the first time today said publicly it was trying to persuade Noriega to leave. ``The nuncio is doing his best to convince Gen. Noriega to abandon the nunciature on his own, by himself,'' spokesman Joaquin Navarro said in Rome. ``At the same time he cannot force Noriega to leave nor can he consign him to U.S forces.'' Navarro said the possibility had been discussed with Noriega since he took refuge at the mission on Sunday. A Panamanian official said Endara's government sent a letter to the Vatican asking that Noriega be expelled from the embassy, where he sought refuge on Sunday. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he did not know whether the government asked that Noriega be turned over to U.S. authorities or to Panama. Navarro today said the Vatican has received no formal request. He also said ``steps'' would be taken if the United States kept up harassment of itw embassy in Panama. U.S. troops ringing the embassy with tanks and armored vehicles continued to blast heavy metal and rock music all night and today. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater suggested it was designed to foil eavesdropping on any negotiations at the palm-studded diplomatic compound. But the music also seemed intended to grate on Noriega's nerves. The playlist included ``You're No Good,'' ``Nowhere to Run, Nowhere to Hide,'' and ``Voodoo Child.'' ``They should keep it up. To see if Noriega gets fed up and leaves,'' said one neighborhood resident, Guadalupe Warner. Many residents have had their pictures taken with soldiers and some make several trips a day to feed the Americans. The Rev. Javier Villanueva, a parish priest helping the papal nuncio, said among the 17 people staying in the embassy with Noriega were Col. Nivaldo Madrinan, chief of Noriega's investigations department, and Capt. Eliezer Gaytan, chief of security. He said four members of the Basque separatist group ETA, along with one of their wives, also had taken shelter there as a precaution. They were in exile in Panama as part of an agreement with the Spanish government, Villanueva said. He refused to identify the 10 others staying at the embassy. On Thursday, U.S. troops stopped a car carrying Cuban Ambassador Lazaro Mora and a companion for inspection and briefly prevented the companion from entering the ambassador's residence because he wasn't carrying the proper identification, a U.S. Embassy spokesman said. The companion got the identification and was later admitted, said the spokesman, William Barr. Also Thursday, the U.S. diplomat said that the 14,000 U.S. troops sent in the invasion would remain at least through February while local security forces are reconstituted. He also acknowledged there was concern about holdovers from the Noriega regime. About 12,000 U.S. troops are permanently stationed in Panama. In Texas, where President Bush was hunting, Fitzwater reiterated the U.S. stance that Noriega should be handed over to the United States to stand trial on drug trafficking charges. Endara, whose government appeared to falter at first, received another boost Thursday when the pro-Noriega Labor Party recognized his government. Party leader Ramon Sieiro, a brother-in-law of Noriega's, read a statement acknowledging Endara's victory in the May 7 balloting that Noriega annulled. Sieiro was a vice presidential candidate on the pro-Noriega coalition ticket in the election. Twenty-three American servicemen and two dependents were killed and 322 Americans were wounded during the invasion, according to the Southern Command. It said 297 Panamanians troops were killed and 123 wounded. The U.S. Embassy official said about 300 Panamanian civilians died in the fighting. He said reports of large numbers of uncounted civilian casualties were unfounded.
